III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry
Description (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and suitable
and able to meet the needs of children and families served by the
agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The foster care worker has physical contact with the foster youth
by nudging the youth's shoulders, shaking the youth and asking
for hugs which has made the youth uncomfortable. Additionally,
the agency workers have threatened and intimidated the
caregivers related to the caregivers’ own children.
Investigation Interviews:
On 6/4/2025, I interviewed Complainant by telephone about the
allegations. Complainant confirmed the information in the
complaint and reported to know the information as true due to her
familial connection to Child A, Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2.
Complainant reported Child A disclosed to her and Caregiver 1
and Caregiver 2 that during a home visit by Foster Care Worker
(FCW) on 5/7/2025, FCW had Child A by the shoulders shaking
her trying to get her to give her information as to who may have
sexually maltreated her. Complainant reported Child A reportedly
named someone just to get FCW to stop. Complainant reported
FCW was aggressive in her questioning of Child A, nudging Child
A’s shoulder, though Child A had told FCW her action made her
uncomfortable. FCW also asked for hugs from Child A during that
home visit and Child A complied out of feeling obligated.
Complainant reported inappropriate contact with Child A by FCW
occurred another time at Child A’s school. FCW arrived at Child
A’s school unannounced and pulled Child A out of class to
interview her. Complainant reported when Child A arrived home,
Child A was very upset about that interaction with FCW; and Child
A reported FCW kept asking her for a hug though, Child A said
she gave verbal and nonverbal clues to FCW that she was
uncomfortable giving her a hug. Complainant did not report what
Child A described the verbal and nonverbal clues to be.
Complainant said Child A reported feeling obliged to hug FCW
because FCW would not let up on questioning her. Complainant
reported Child A is now concerned FCW will come to the school
and will remove her from Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2.
2

Complainant further reported FCW has lied on Caregiver 1 and
Caregiver 2, by saying they were refusing to allow her to see the
children; accused Caregiver 1 of having a fake identification; and
during a Zoom meeting threatened to remove Caregiver 1’s and
Caregiver 2’s children. Complainant reported the latter verbal
threat was made in the context of if Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2
do not do what the agency tells them; should children services get
involved; their children could be at risk for removal. Complainant
reported FCW’s behavior, has caused significant distress for Child
A; and that is seen as intimidating and hostile by her and
Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2. Complainant also reported she
does not believe FCW meant any harm, related to her affection
toward Child A, but FCW goes overboard.
Complainant added Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2 had a meeting
related to the case, where FCW and Foster Care Supervisor
(FCS) “tag teamed” against Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2 “without
being rude to them”, meaning they went back-to-back with issues
related to things the agency was concerned about. FCW and FCS
told them if anyone came to the home that the agency did not
have clearances for, it could get them in trouble. Complainant
expressed concern that FCW and FCS are trying to set Caregiver
1 and Caregiver 2 up for failure because the agency did not want
Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2 to have placement of Child A and her
siblings. Complainant reported the judge ordered the children
placed with Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2; and given that
Complainant believes FCW may be trying to find a reason to not
have the children remain in the home. Complainant did not give
any specific evidence to support her beliefs. Complainant denied
Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2 requesting a formal meeting to voice
concerns related to FCW and FCS.
On 6/4/2025, I interviewed Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) about
the allegations by telephone. FCS reported awareness of the
complaint allegations. She denied she or FCW being threatening
or intimidating toward the foster children or Caregiver 1 and
Caregiver 2 in any fashion. She denied any knowledge of FCW
making requests for physical attention from Child A, like hugs; or
of Child A being uncomfortable with FCW. FCS reported FCW has
never mentioned that matter as a concern to her; nor had
Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2; or anyone else. FCS reported she
has accompanied FCW on a home visit to Caregiver 1 and
Caregiver 2’s home. She has observed FCW engaging with
Child A several times; and she had never witnessed FCW to be
inappropriate with Child A. She said FCW has always been
3

respectful of boundaries with Child A and she has no reason to
believe this allegation to be true. She reported FCW has serviced
Child A’s case since 2/20/2025, and FCW will be leaving the
agency; FCW’s last day is 6/5/2025.
As to her reportedly threatening that children service could
remove Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2’s children, FCS admitted
she/the agency encouraged Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2 to
cooperate with the agency; and that during a Family Team
Meeting (FTM)with Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2 on 4/24/25 she
explained that if in the future children services were to conduct an
investigation pertaining to possible maltreatment, while the
children are in their care, their children could be involved. She
stated she never used the word removed, nor told Caregiver 1 and
Caregiver 2 that children service would take away their children.
FCS reported prior to this complaint, neither Caregiver 1
Caregiver 2, nor anyone else requested a meeting with her, or any
person higher up in the agency’s administration to voice concern
about FCW or any staff person. FCS reported she knows
Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2, and family members did not like the
fact that they were going to the school to talk with the children, but
they were doing so because they had concerns about the
placement, in that Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2 had not been
forthcoming with some information, like how often the children’s
birth mother had been visiting the children in the home, the
children having missed a number of days of school, and that Child
B had been having very frequent urination accidents at school.
The agency also had concerns that Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2
may have been influencing what the children reported to FCW
during home visits: so, the agency believed FCW visiting the
children at school would be appropriate as it would allow for
privacy for FCW and children to talk. FCS admitted the children
were placed with Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2 against
the agency’s recommendation but denied any efforts to sabotage
the placement. She reported the children came into care due to
sexual maltreatment on Child A and that the agency was still in
the process of assessing the situation. She said the family is very
close-knit, many family members seemed to be in denial of
the maltreatment. She reported further that Caregiver 1 initially
did not want placement of the children; and there was
concern that Caregiver 1 may have been coerced by other
family members to commit to the placement. FCS said the agency
was trying to ensure for the children’s safety and stability to
ensure the placement was safe and appropriate to meet the
children’s needs.
4

On 6/4/25 I interviewed Foster Care Worker(FCW) by
telephone. FCW reported awareness of this complaint as it was
discussed with the placement collaboration unit today; and that
the agency is aware of who the complainant is. FCW denied the
allegations; and reported information similarly to FCS as it
pertained to Child A and her siblings placement with Caregiver 1
and Caregiver 2; the agency’s placement concerns; and the
agency’s continued assessments to ensure the children’s safety.
She reported she would not purposefully say or do anything to
intimidate or harass Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2, because she
wanted them to work with the agency. FCW reported she knew
Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2 were not pleased about actions she
had to initiate around children services referrals on past issues
mentioned by Child A, but she denied Caregiver 1 and Caregiver
2 ever reporting to her or her supervisor, that they felt she had
overstepped with her interaction with the children.
FCW reported she was assigned Child A and her siblings’
case on 2/20/25. She reported a positive relationship with
Child A and the other children. She said these children have
always been hands on and have always wanted to talk to her.
She said the children attach to strangers quickly and did so with
their foster parents prior to their replacement. She said Child A
opened up to her quickly; and when Child A is stressed,
can’t say what she wants, journaling, writing things down has
helped Child A express herself. FCW reported Child A had
expressed to her that her family has never listened to her, and she
couldn’t tell them things about the past, because no one believes
her. Child A named her grandmother as one of those people.
FCW reported since Child A’s placement with Caregiver 1 and
Caregiver 2, Child A has changed drastically. Child A has become
unreceptive to talking to her about things. FCW reported
Social Worker, whom Child A was seeing due to high
stress levels around visitation with her birth mom, had also
reported Child A becoming quiet and not wanting to talk with
anyone. FCW reported because of this change in Child A’s
behavior, as well as reports from the school of school absences,
she and FCS believed talking with Child A at school would be
appropriate as a school visit would allow privacy for Child A to
express herself away from Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2’s view.
FCW reported making a school visit on 5/21/2025, at which
time Child A disclosed information to her about a past
maltreatment of her when she was eight. FCW said she reported
that matter to children services that same day and an FTM
5

occurred with staff and Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2 on 5/23/2025
related to Child A and her siblings’ placement.
FCW denied Child A being resistant to her or uncomfortable
with her at the school visit on 5/21/2025 or the home visit
on 5/6/2025 where Child A disclosed a past maltreatment by a
cousin, which was also reported to children services, or at other
home visits. FCW admitted during the school visit with Child A on
5/21/2025, Child A told her, she was afraid that FCW may come to
the school to remove her from her placement, because FCW was
always asking her questions. FCW reported this was the first time
Child A had ever indicated a fear with her and she assured Child
A she was not in trouble, and that she was not seeking to remove
her from her placement.
FCW also reported being aware that Child A does not like hugs,
and reported she told Child A that was ok. If Child A felt
anxious or needed a hug Child A could ask for a hug, and Child A
was okay with that. FCW reported the conservation with hugs
came up at the school visit because it bothered her that Child A
was reporting not wanting to see her. FCW denied any attempt to
hug Child A at that 5/21/2025 school visit. She said she gave
Child A her space. FCW also denied hugging or trying to hug
Child A in the past without Child A’s approval. She said Child A
has given her hugs freely in the past, and by Child A’s choice.
FCW denied ever shaking or pushing Child A in any fashion
at any home visit. She admitted she may have nudged Child A’s
shoulder at the home visit on 5/6/2025. She recalled Child A
standing close to her and touching Child A’s shoulder as to
say “come on”, or “you know”. FCW reported barley remembering
the touch. She denied Child A saying don’t touch me or voicing
any discomfort. She reported she had offered extra time to
Caregiver 1 and Caregiver 2 related to Child A; and Child A,
during the school visit told her that since she is with her family,
she no longer needs FCW’s help. FCW reported the latter
statement by Child A concerned her because one of the other
siblings had reported their caregivers had told them not to tell
FCW anything.
On 6/11/2025 I spoke with Social Worker (SSW) by telephone.
SSW reported Child A has never mentioned a concern or fear of
FCW or any agency worker. She stated the only person Child had
expressed a concern with had been Child A’s mother. SSW stated
to her knowledge FCW has only visited Child A at the school
once. She observed that interaction for a while; FCW used SSW’s
office to talk with Child A. SSW reported that the interaction
6

between FCW and Child A was appropriate. Child A did not report
or show any signs of being fearful of FCW; and FCW never tried
to hug or obtain physical attention from Child A. SSW reported
the only person Child A has talked about not wanting to be
hugged by is Child A’s mother. She said she and Child A have
discussed comfortable touches and it being okay for Child A to
say she does not want a hug. SSW stated in her opinion, Child A
viewed FCW and talking with FCW as a safe space. SSW
explained that when Child A has been upset at school, or has
been anxious around seeing her mother, Child A has asked to call
or text FCW.
SSW also reported noticing a change in Child A’s behavior in the
last several weeks. She reported since Child A moved to her
current relative placement, Child A has not wanted to talk with her,
or office staff. She reported Child A is a very articulate child who
does well at expressing herself or writing down her feelings; but
now Child A is not saying anything. SSW wondered whether
someone is telling Child A not to talk to people, because Child A
had been comfortable doing so, especially when she thinks, no
one can overhear her.
On 7/11/2025 I spoke with Caregiver 2 by telephone. Caregiver 2
initially stated she had no major concerns with FCW. She stated it
was more a concern of Child A not liking what FCW would do to
get information from her. Caregiver 2 stated FCW “would placate”
Child A by acting like her friend, say things like” girl you can tell
me” or putting her hand on Child A’s shoulder to get Child A to
disclose things to her. Caregiver 2 said they were also concerned
with FCW going to the school to talk Child A; not liking the school
due to a kid calling Child A a monkey; and FCW not having a
concern with the school. Caregiver 2 said FCW thought she and
her mom were putting things in Child A’s head to influence Child A
negatively against the agency, but that was not true. She also
reported during a ZOOM meeting FCW and FCS talked about her
and her mom being at risk of getting involved with children
services if they did not do what the agency asked them.
Caregiver 2 reported not understanding why her son, an adult who
lives out of state would need to have a clearance to visit the
children in the home. Caregiver 2 denied informing the agency of
these concerns, but believed the agency was aware.
On 7/15/2025, during a foster home visit, I interviewed Caregiver
1, who was present with her Grandmother; and at times
Grandmother chimed into the conversation. I also interviewed
Child A alone.
7

Caregiver 1 reported FCW was trying to make it seem to them as
if Child A did not want to be hugged, but it was that Child A did not
want to be hugged by FCW. Caregiver 1 reported when FCW
visited her home FCW would insist on speaking with Child A
upstairs with the door closed. When FCW would not get the
answer she wanted, FCW would shake Child A and tell Child A
that “you can tell me”. Caregiver 1 did not witness the
aforementioned interactions between FCW and Child A, Child A
told them what occurred. Caregiver 1 denied Child A ever telling
her FCW pushed her or made her fall. Caregiver 1 reported as of
now it will be her and Grandmother caring for the children. She
said Caregiver 2, who had cared for the children at night, just
moved back to Arizona, and she would be informing the agency of
this.
Caregiver 1 and Grandmother expressed concern that the
agency did not want the children placed in their home; had
accused Caregiver 1 of having a fake identification, of her and
Caregiver 2 not sharing information with the agency related to the
children’s school, or about Child B having wetting accidents at
school. Caregiver 1 denied that. She expressed concern that the
agency was assuming she could not take care of the children
because she is young. She reported being 29 but looking 19. She
reported FCW’s initial home visits seemed friendly, supportive, but
the visits increased. Caregiver 1 said when she complained about
the home visits, FCW began to visit the children at school.
Caregiver 1 and Grandmother also expressed the same concern
as reported by Caregiver 2 about FCW and FCS stating during a
meeting that their children could become involved with children
services and get taken. Caregiver 1 reported she does not have
any children so that did not make sense to her. Caregiver 1
reported relief that FCW is no longer the children’s foster care
worker. She said she believed FCW had gotten some information
Child A had reported about an adult cousin who may have hurt
her, mixed up with a child by the same name and that FCW was
not supportive of the family keeping the children. Caregiver 1
reported the new foster care worker is “fine”, she does not
pressure the children, and her attitude is different from FCW, more
positive.
Child A reported FCW visited the home twice a month when she
was first placed with Caregiver 1. FCW later started coming three
or four times a month, and even came unannounced, randomly
showing up for a home visit after 5:00pm. Child A said FCW even
came in a van once that said state department and that was scary.
8

Child A reported FCW would speak with her alone and FCW
would ask her questions like “how are you doing?” or “are you
eating?” She said sometimes if she didn’t make eye contact with
FCW, or FCW did not “understand where I was coming from”,
FCW would ask her if she was sure about her answers, as though
she was lying. She said FCW would pretend to play with her, like
touching her shoulder and say, “oh you can tell me, when I was
telling her the truth”. She said FCW once told her to “stay in a
child’s place”, meaning to act like a kid, while also telling her to
help out with her sister and brother. Child A reported once during
a home visit FCW pushed her shoulder with a little force and she
fell on the floor and FCW stood over her. Child A said Caregiver 1
came over and saw her on the floor. She said FCW did not
apologize to her because FCW said she tripped.
Child A denied being afraid of FCW or of FCW hurting her. She
also denied being hugged by FCW when it was unwanted. When
I asked her specifically if she was ever touched by FCW when she
did not want to be touched, Child A reported “yes”. She reported
FCW touched her shoulder and that happened more than once.
Child A admitted FCW may have touched her to comfort her, but
then she stated, “it was a kind of madness and was not warm”.
Child A did not explain what she meant by that statement, but
stated she does not miss FCW as her worker.
Documents Reviewed:
Child A’s MISACWIS file which showed:
• Child A and her brother and sister Child B and Child C were
made temporary court wards on 2/20/2025.
• The children were placed in a foster home on 2/20/2025 and
replaced with their current relative placements on 4/24/2025.
• FCW was assigned the children’s case on 2/20/2025.
• The children initial and updated service plan indicated the
following:
o The children had been doing well in the foster home;
were placed with their current caregiver against the
agency’s recommendation, but the children and
caregiver were adjusting okay. Additionally, there
were concerns with the birth mother visiting the
caregiver’s home; and with school issues as
mentioned by the agency staff when interviewed.
o FCW’s “pop up” home visit to the caregiver’s home
when she spoke with the family about concerns and
spoke with Child A. Child A reported feeling good and
not needing FCW’s help any longer because of that,
9

while also reporting to FCW she had a secret to tell
FCW which FCW cannot tell anyone.
o FCW’s 5/21/2025 unannounced school visit where
she spoke with the three foster children. It noted Child
A reported she was uncomfortable to see/talk with
FCW; and FCW denoted that was the first time Child
A had reported such an action.
o There were no reports of concerns noted in the
service plan related to FCW or agency staff.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed there is insufficient
evidence to substantiate the allegations as described in the
complaint; or to support a lack of responsible character or
suitability of the staff to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency. The agency had concerns with Caregiver 1
and Caregiver 2 and were further assessing the caregivers to
ensure safety in the children’s placement. Conversely Caregiver 1
and Caregiver 2 had concerns with the agency staff, did not feel
supported or trusted and the two parties did not appear to be
clearly communicating these concerns directly with each other.
Additionally, Child A denied unwanted physical contact with FCW
with the exception of her shoulder being pushed by FCW; which
she reported resulted in her falling and Caregiver 1 was aware of
that, but Caregiver 1 denied this.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
